doc.title: Korea Cosmetics: Monthly tracker
doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/Jul-25_ DFS weakness continued on daigou weakness; Cosrx_Laneige underperformed in the US_2025-09-02

passages.text: We summarize the July updates of our Korea cosmetics tracker across DFS sales and relevant performance data in the China and US markets below. Key highlights include:

1. Korea DFS sales continued to decline at \(8\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(-9\%\) yoy in Jun) mainly dragged by weak foreigner sales at \(-14\%\) yoy over \(-31\%\) decline of spending per cap likely due to less Daigou, despite local Korean spending growing at \(8\%\) yoy. Compared to pre-COVID for the same period in 2019, total DFS turnover in Jul pulled back to \(39\%\) from \(48\%\) in Jun 2025.

2. US market: Korea cosmetics exports continued to grow at \(+18\%\) yoy in Jul (vs. \(+22\%\) yoy in Jun) primarily led by the US and Japan at \(21\% /12\%\) yoy, which was offset by exports to mainland China declining at \(14\%\) yoy. On Amazon US, Cosrx Jul GMV declined at \(20\%\) yoy (vs. \(+26\%\) yoy in Jun) and continued to underperform with total channel growth of \(1\%\) yoy, while Laneige turned negative in the month (-28% yoy vs. \(+71\%\) yoy in Jun) and underperformed vs. the total beauty category. Number of shipments to the US overall showed divergence within the brands we track, with Silicon2 growing at \(83\%\) yoy, while Amore/Cosrx/Cosmax declined at \(3\% /13\% /45\%\) yoy in the month.
3. China market: On major online platforms, LG HH outperformed other MNCs at \(+9\%\) yoy, while Amore lagged with \(49\%\) yoy decline with DD% decline across all core brands.
We are Sell-rated on Amore Pacific C/G, LGHH.

China Consumer Conection: Online Brand Tracker: divergence into low season; White goods/RVC Led: Beauty/Sports accelerated on easier base China Cosmetics: Monthly tracker: Jul- 25: Jul accelerates on easier base; Mass/local better than 18 while premium/MNCs turned negative China/South Korea Cosmetics: Global Cosmetics readacross: 2Q initial Onshore recovery: ongoing DFS pressure; Non- Korean brands recover in US

Korea DFS. The Korea Duty Free Association (KDFA) announced Korea's Jul 2025 DFS turnover at US\$669mn, implying \(- 8\%\) yoy (vs. \(- 9\%\) yoy in Jun 25), mainly dragged by weak foreigner sales at \(- 14\%\) yoy despite Korean spending growth at \(8\%\) yoy. Compared to pre- COVID for the same period in 2019, total DFS turnover in Jul came in at \(39\%\) , vs. \(48\%\) in Jun 2025.

Shopper- wise, Korean spending grew at \(8\%\) yoy led by \(7\%\) yoy in per capita spending while DFS traffic came in flattish. Total foreigner spending declined at \(14\%\) yoy dragged by per capita spending declining at \(31\%\) yoy despite \(25\%\) yoy increase in traffic. Separately, on a KRW basis, monthly market revenue growth stood at \(- 9\%\) yoy/- \(15\%\) mom (vs. \(- 10\%\) yoy/+ \(3\%\) mom in Jun 2025) post the \(0.6\%\) yoy KRW appreciation vs. USD in the month.

Exhibit 1: Korea DFS turnover came in at US\$669mn, implying \(-8\%\) yoy, mainly dragged by weak foreigner sales at \(-14\%\) yoy despite Korean spending growth at \(8\%\) yoy. Korea DFS - Nationwide Jul 2025 sales results
Monthly salesYTD salesMonthly sales as % of 2019 levelMay-24Jun-24Aug-24Sep-24Oct-24Nov-24Dec-24Jan-25Feb-25Mar-25Apr-25May-25Jun-25Jul-25Jul-25Jul-24%yoyyoyyoyyoyyoyyyyyyyy
Exhibit 2: Compared to pre-COVID for the game period in 2019, total DFS turnover in Jul came in at \(39\%\) , vs. \(48\%\) in Jun 2025.
Source:Korea Duty Free Association

Exhibit 3: Total foreign spending declined at \(14\%\) yoy dragged by per capita spending declining at \(31\%\) yoy despite \(25\%\) yoy increase in traffic. Korea DFS industry monthly sales by visitor type and foreigner ASP
Source:Korea Duty Free Association

Cosmetics exports from Korea. Korea cosmetics exports totaled US \(982mn (+18\%\) yoy) in Jul 2025. Region- wise, exports to mainland China (accounting for \(15\%\) of total cosmetics exports in Jun) were down \(14\%\) yoy (vs. \(- 11\%\) yoy in Jun). Exports to the US (accounting for \(22\%\) of total cosmetics exports in Jun) jumped \(21\%\) yoy, while exports to Japan (accounting for \(9\%\) of total cosmetics exports in Jun) were up \(12\%\) yoy during the month.
Exhibit 4: If comparing to pre- COVID to remove base effects, total export value in Jul 25 reached 192% of Jun 19 level, primarily led by strong increase in the US and Japan.
Exhibit 6: On a yoy basis, total Korea cosmetics exports grew at 18% yoy in Jul 2025, with exports to mainland China down 14% yoy.
Source: Korea International Trade Association, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 5: Mainland China and HK together accounted for 19% of total cosmetics exports from Korea in Jul 2025, while US/Japan shares accounted for 22%/9% respectively.
Source: Korea International Trade Association
Exhibit 7: Exports to the US/Japan jumped 21%/12% yoy respectively in Jul, indicating ongoing healthy momentum of K-beauty brands in non-China overseas.
Source: Korea International Trade Association
Korea domestic cosmetics retail sales declined at - 1% yoy in Jun vs. average total retail sales growth at 1% yoy. Of note, online sales, which accounted for c. 41% of total
cosmetics retail sales in Jun, was up \(13\%\) yoy during the month.
Exhibit 8: Korea domestic cosmetics retail sales declined at \(- 1\%\) yoy in Jun vs. average total retail sales growth at \(1\%\) yoy. Monthly retail sales yoy of total retail vs. cosmetics
Korea monthly retail sales yoy of total goods vs. cosmetics
Source:Korean Statistical Information Service
Exhibit 9: Compared to Jun 2021, cosmetics retail sales CAGR came in at \(- 3\%\) yoy in Jun 2025, vs. \(- 4\%\) yoy in May South Korea monthly retail sales vs. 2021 of total goods vs. cosmetics
Korea monthly retail sales CAGR vs. 2021 of total goods vs. cosmetics
Source:Korean Statistical Information Service
Below we track major Korea cosmetic brands' performance in the US beauty market.

Online GMV & SNS followers. Amorepacific's Cosrx posted US \(8.9mn (- 20\%\) yoy, vs. \(26\%\) yoy in Jun) sales on Amazon US in Jul 2025, which implies c. \(0.2\%\) market share within total Beauty and Personal Care sales in the channel. Meanwhile, Laneige posted US \(8.1mn sales (- 28\%\) yoy, vs. \(+71\%\) yoy in Jun) on Amazon US during the month, which implies c. \(0.2\%\) share within the total Beauty and Personal Care sales in the channel.
Exhibit 10: Cosrx sales on Amazon US declined at \(20\%\) yoy in Jul
Source: Moojing, Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 11: Laneige turned to \(28\%\) yoy decline on Amazon US in July
Source: Moojing, Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 12: Number of followers for Laneige/Cosrx on Tiktok reached 1,100k/268k as of Jul 2025
Exhibit 16: Silicon2's shipments to the US grew at \(83\%\) yoy in July
\\* TEU: Twenty-foot equivalent unit
Exhibit 17: Cosmax's shipments to the US were down \(45\%\) yoy in July
\\* TEU: Twenty-foot equivalent unit
Source: Import Yeti, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Source: Import Yeti, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We supplement our analysis with data from HundredX, a mission- based data and insights company that takes an innovative approach to monitoring consumer perceptions and gathering consumer feedback to understand trends across \(80+\) industries and \(3,000+\) brands. HundredX analyzes collective opinions of everyday customers and evaluates how their priorities influence purchasing decisions and attitudes toward businesses and brands.

Based on HundredX data, 3- month trailing Net Purchase Intent for overall make up & skincare industry in the US remained negative in Jul, which points to overall weak beauty consumption demand in the US, while we note both NPI and NPS for dermocosmetics brands slightly trended above those of industry. Looking by segments, both NPI and NPS for skincare brands continued to trend above those of color make up brands during the month.
Exhibit 18: Net Purchase Intent for dermo brands trended above that of total industry in July T3M through Jul'25
Source: HundredX, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 19: Gap between Net Purchase Intent of skincare and color make up brands continued in July T3M through Jul'25
Source: HundredX, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 20: Net Promotor Scores for dermobrands trended above that of total industry in the US in July T3M through Jul'25
Source: HundredX, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 21: Net Promoter Scores for skincare brands continued to trend above that of color make up brands in July T3M through Jul'25
Source: HundredX, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Increasing popularity of K- culture is creating a favorable backdrop for Korean cosmetics brands overseas. Our analysis on Google Trends suggests overall consumer interest toward K- beauty and Korea skincare is still showing healthy momentum in the US.
Exhibit 22: US consumers' interest in Korean beauty and skincare remains healthy based on Google Search trend.
Source: Google Trends (https://www.google.com/trends), Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 23: US consumers' interest in Cosrx/Laneige based on Google Search
Source: Google Trends (https://www.google.com/trends), Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

In Jul, mass/local brands took back shares from premium/MNC, reversing the trend observed during 618. Shanghai Jahwa/Marubi/Kans led with \(58\% /51\% /48\%\) yoy growth, while Giant/Perfect Diary/Botanee grew by \(24\% /7\% /2\%\) yoy. MGP/Proya/Bloomage underperformed with \(9\% /17\% /48\%\) yoy decline.

For Korean brands, LG HH was the sole MNC group we track that saw yoy growth in Jul, outperforming at \(+9\%\) yoy, while Amore lagged with \(49\%\) yoy decline with DD% decline across all core brands.

Exhibit 24: In Jul, mass/local brands took back shares from premium/MNC, reversing the trend observed during 618. For Korean brands, LG HH was the sole MNC group we track that saw you growth in Jul, outperforming at \(+9\%\) you, while Amore lagged with \(49\%\) you decline. The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.

You are permitted to store, display, analyze, modify, reformat, and print the information made available to you via this service only for your own use. You may not resell or reverse engineer this information to calculate or develop any index for disclosure and/or marketing or create any other derivative works or commercial product(s), data or offerings(s) without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. You are not permitted to publish, transmit, or otherwise reproduce this information, in whole or in part, in any format to any third party without the express written consent of Goldman Sachs. This foregoing restriction includes, without limitation, using, extracting, downloading or retrieving this information, in whole or in part, to train or finetune a machine learning or artificial intelligence system, or to provide or reproduce this information, in whole or in part, as a prompt or input to any such system.
